data.title: The Childhood of Maxim Gorky (1938)
data.meta_description: Young Maxim grows up under the czarist regime with his grandparents as guardians. Continually demeaned by his martinet grandfather, Maxim is drawn to his warm-hearted grandmother, who instills in him the willingness to pursue his writing muse.
data.text:
Ausencia de Mark Donskoi

Cada invierno se lleva a varios de los viejos directores, cada vez menos numerosos y más olvidados, que sobreviven. El cineasta soviético Mark Donskoi —nacido en Odessa (Ucrania) el 8 de marzo de 1901 y casi totalmente ignorado en España— resistió el invierno, pero murió en los primeros días del mes de abril, cumplidos ya los ochenta años de edad. En su memoria, la Filmoteca Nacional proyectó, a las horas de menor asistencia de público, dos de las veinticuatro películas que realizó entre 1927 y 1974: Raduga («El arco iris», 1943) y —¡sin subtítulos!— Detstvo Gorkogo (1938), primera parte de la célebre trilogía de Máximo Gorki.

A la vista de ambas, pero sobre todo de la…

One of the most beautiful period pieces I've ever seen in my life; a film that gets the environment and the characters perfectly right. The young Gorki and everything around him is like from his best works, the early novellas that to me represent some of the greatest work of art seem to be already being written here. Not only this but it seems that Donskoy reaches to reach for "Russian mentality and sensibility" in this work, the characterizations are rich like from beautifully illustrated book and the realism draws from the world captured by a poet. For a film of the time, there seems to be nothing of the usual propagandist purposes even if the themes basically fit to…

The Soviet classics and obscurities marathon continues...

(Note: This won't be a regular, complete review, as I've fallen ill and need rest.)

The first film in one of world cinema's most significant trilogies, Mark Donskoy's The Childhood of Maxim Gorky succeeds in just about every way possible, balancing romanticism of childhood with an understanding of both the injustices of an impoverished upbringing and the character-building that can result. As works of screen naturalism in the 1930s, the Gorky trilogy films have few to compare to apart from the films of Ozu.
